All,

We are currently having a similar discussion in a different scientifi=
c
domain. While I will admit to a quantitative bias, there are times when
m=
ethods that lead (or tend) to qualitative patterns yield important,
identif=
iable information. This information can be compared and contrasted,
but the=
 formal languages for this purpose, like category theory, are still
quite y=
oung.  The effects of a Newtonian, deterministic  view of science
still bia=
ses even statistical and quantum phenomena.

I think what sometimes gives q=
ualitative patterns in scientific research a
bad rep is outlined in Jerry W=
illis=92 book =93Foundations of Qualitative
Research=94, often exemplified =
by the Sokal Scandal or the Milgram Experiment.
The question centers around=
 what people consider =91science=92, and this seems
to vary much more than =
one would imagine.

Ken Lloyd

Subject: [neat] Re=
: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results

=A0 
Hi Randy, I have a couple comm=
ents below. Please don't take it as
overly critical - I'm much more interes=
ted in the issue of where an
unquestioning drive towards quantification wil=
l lead us, so I'm just
exploring that issue through your suggestions. I res=
pect your view and
understand that many share it.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.=
com, "rhiever489" wrote:
>
> Hey Jeff,
>
> Sure, but those statements are a=
 bit "cowboy science-y." Let me show
you
> how those statements can (and li=
kely will) be translated:
> "A single (non-reproduced?) study has suggested=
 that targeted
evolution
> does not work very well (with Picbreeder?). Our =
method can achieve an
> error of zero (data not shown). Thus, comparing our=
 method with
targeted
> evolution is pointless."
> Performing such a quanti=
tative comparison would kill two birds with
one
> stone: (1) it reproduces =
the findings that Ken made* in a 3D domain,
and
> (2) it would address the =
readers' concerns related to the goal of the
> paper, particularly by direc=
tly showing that your method produces more
> accurate CPPN-based representa=
tions of 3D objects than the "leading"
> (only) method. For a methods paper=
, that is an important statement to
> make. Thus, there is value in making =
a quantitative comparison here,
and
> it's not an arbitrary checkbox.
> * I=
'm not suggesting that Ken did/does bad or unreliable work, but
> reproduci=
ng results that you're building off of is an important part
of
> science --=
 especially when you're applying those results in a new
domain
> (2D object=
s vs. 3D objects).
>

So you really would prefer that Jeff would fill up se=
veral pages of this
short paper instead with a comparison between his new m=
ethod and a
reproduction of my old target-based evolution experiment with B=
rian
Woolley, even though that's not the subject of this paper? Jeff's
meth=
od for reproducing these objects is not an optimization method so of
course=
 it is essentially perfect, so why bother comparing it to an
optimization m=
ethod? The point of this paper is what happens once you
evolve beyond such =
reproductions, not the perfection of the
reproductions themselves.

If you =
were a reviewer and succeeded in forcing Jeff to switch this
paper to inclu=
de such a comparison, do you really think the resulting
loss of text on the=
 real topic of the paper (i.e. what happens after you
evolve further) would=
 not actually reduce its value?

This suggested change might be an example =
of how demanding
quantification where it is unneeded can actually damage a =
paper and
distort its original intent, but I'm curious how you see it.

> I=
t's a really bad assumption (that many of us make) that someone will
> want=
 to follow up on our work. Yes, it's good to point out future
> research di=
rections from the work, but the mindset that everyone will
> want to follow=
 up on our work can be damaging to the research field.
> Everyone wants to =
be the thought leader and establish a "new" research
> path, and that's why=
 we see so many people establishing new research
> platforms and whatnot ev=
ery year and talking about all the cool
research
> that it enables. Then by=
 the next year, that platform has fallen into
> obscurity because no one wa=
nted to actually do that future work, and
> thus no one really learned anyt=
hing from the paper introducing that
> research platform.
> That's a big re=
ason why I think qualitative/methods/proof of concept
> papers (whatever yo=
u want to call them -- they're the same) are not
very
> useful to publish a=
s full papers, and are better suited as a poster or
> late-breaking abstrac=
t.
>

These sentiments surprised me. Why is it a bad assumption that someon=
e
would want to follow up on your work? What is the point of publishing
som=
ething if you assume that no one would want to follow up on it? What
could =
be more important than what might come next thanks to your
contribution? If=
 anything I'd like to see longer future work sections
so I have some idea w=
hy people think their ideas are important.

I'm also not clear on why a pro=
of of concept should be relegated to a
poster. After all, there's only one =
proof-of-concept in the known
universe of evolution producing human intelli=
gence and it inspired our
entire research field.

If I evolved a single Hyp=
erNEAT neural network with human-level
intelligence but could not do it aga=
in, would you prefer that the result
remains reported only in a poster? Wou=
ld you question the capabilities
of HyperNEAT because it "only" evolved hum=
an-level intelligence once?

Personally I think our field will be forced to=
 shift inevitably to more
proofs of concept because evolution at its most i=
mpressive doesn't like
doing cool stuff more than once. No interesting imag=
e on Picbreeder
will ever be discovered again. No creature on Earth will ev=
er evolve
again in the history of the planet. Finding something once is goo=
d
enough for me to want to know about it, and often will be as good as it
g=
ets. The fact that human intelligence evolved once is amazing enough
and me=
rits thousands of research articles, as it has indeed provoked.

Best,

ken=
